### 06-28-2020

#185 #186 #189 implements the following screenshot ([demo](https://athensresearch.github.io/athens/cards.html#!/athens.devcards.filters)). Next steps are to implement actual link parsing at the page-level, and then only include/exclude blocks based on those filters.

### 05-15-2020

After a certain number of links, it's quite difficult to manage all the filters. I believe some Roam users are now using `{{query}}`s to achieve a similar goal of filtering information.

The design space is likewise broad as in #26: What is the actual user goal and what might be some various solutions?

![Screen Shot 2020-05-15 at 7 38 47 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8952138/82104149-b2d0ea80-96e3-11ea-9ba5-0c5e685df405.png)

comments.body: I've still been thinking about this. We did some initial design exploration around making the filters easier to read and use. The idea was that, we could communicate the filter's status with color instead of requiring it to change locations into a separate "added" or "excluded" area. This concept could be used as a sidebar that leverages the vertical orientation to display the filters in a list. This type of component could also allow for filtering a long list of filters with a search bar at the top. To your point, @tangjeff0, the real question is, "Do we want filters?" Or, should we invest the design effort in making queries more accessible and easy to use? I lean toward the latter, but I would still like to hear from someone who uses this filter functionality a lot (if that person exists).
